body: @glenn-jocher Thanks for your reply. Let me try this out and please keep this ticket open for further feedback.

@SiyangXie yeah no problem. Also make sure you `git pull` to get the latest updates. Also if you train with the `--prebias` flag this typically helps a bit as well. 

Most importantly, you need to look at your results.png to see when your validation losses start overtraining, and if they don't then you need to train longer, ideally 300-1000 epochs for smaller datasets.

> @SiyangXie you should use the default ultraltyics68.pt weights to start your training along with yolov3-spp.cfg, they'll produce better results faster than yolov3.weights or darknet53.conv.74.
> 
> Your last image can be tweaked to reduce iou_thres in detect.py to remove the dual hat detection.
> 
> In terms of everything else, you simply need to tune your training to your specific situation. You can also evolve your hyperparameters for your specific situation. See #392

If I want to reproduce the detection as much precise as yolov3.weights, is it the right way to use ultraltyics68.pt for training on COCO?
@SiyangXie ultralytics68.pt is better than yolov3.weights. See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3#map
@glenn-jocher If I want to just detect persons, I need to use ultralytics68.pt as my weights to retrain COCO dataset, is that correct?

@SiyangXie yes you can do that,  or you can also just use ultralytics68.pt with the `--classes` flag to only pass people detections (class 0):

```bash
$ python3 detect.py --weights ultralytics68.pt --classes 0
Namespace(agnostic_nms=False, cfg='cfg/yolov3-spp.cfg', classes=[0], conf_thres=0.3, device='', fourcc='mp4v', half=False, img_size=416, iou_thres=0.5, names='data/coco.names', output='output', save_txt=False, source='data/samples', view_img=False, weights='weights/ultralytics68.pt')
Using CPU

image 1/2 data/samples/bus.jpg: 416x320 4 persons, Done. (0.775s)
image 2/2 data/samples/zidane.jpg: 256x416 2 persons, Done. (0.616s)
Results saved to /Users/glennjocher/PycharmProjects/yolov3/output
Done. (1.641s)
```

@glenn-jocher Okay... but I'm not sure if it optimizes the memory use, because it's still using the same weights for detection, right? Does it still detect 80 classes but only labels the person class?

And also what COCO dataset should I use if I want to retrain from scratch?
@SiyangXie yes this is correct, it uses the full ultralytics68.pt weights for detection. You can us any dataset you want naturally, as long as it's in the correct format.
I'll close this issue for now as the original issue appears to have been resolved, and/or no activity has been seen for some time. Feel free to comment if this is not the case.
